ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a highly recommended course. While it will require some effort on the student's part, it has a lot to offer both the experimentally and theoretically motivated student.

yes! It is essential for any upcoming scientist who aspires to be successful, as it lays the fundamental groundwork to noise, statistics, probability theory, stochastic process, and delves into the deeper connections between the fields, including a novel look at QM in terms of information theory.

I would recommend this course to other students in physics or many other fields. The provided lecture notes, though not a polished and complete textbook on the material, are also good and the homework problems worthwhile.
Physics 677 is relevant to anyone who works in measuring sensitive signals, which is to say almost all experimentalists and many theorists.

No...Only if they are going to do research in one of the lab's in Becton that is closely related to that field. This was an extremely technical course, one that should not be taken by the cursory student.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I am sure this will contribute to my research.
This is very useful in the course of an experimental research project inescapably infused with noise at every stage.
